subject: Fake HTTP request/response implementation
msgSnippet: Hey JB, I want this kind of thing again today, and remembered your junit group post.  Ship anything yet?  :) Or does anyone know of an implementation that
messageBody:
Hey JB,

I want this kind of thing again today, and remembered your junit group
post. Ship anything yet? :)

Or does anyone know of an implementation that isn't as brittle as the
com.mockobjects implementation?

-Kevin


On Mon, 07 Mar 2005 19:26:27 -0500, J. B. Rainsberger
<jbrains@...> wrote:
> As for a /fake/ HTTP request interface, I find myself building that
> thing over and over again. I should ship something, shouldn't I?
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing



On Mon, 07 Mar 2005 19:26:27 -0500, J. B. Rainsberger
<jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Kevin Klinemeier wrote:
> > I agree, I use the HTTP Mock API, and I hate that it has discrete
> > expectations about the *number* of times an accessor is called. I
> > looked desperately for a way to turn this off/tell it I don't care,
> > but I didn't find it. For now, I just deal, but if I found a mock
> > HTTP interface that was complete and didn't have this behavior, I'd be
> > very tempted to jump ship.
>
> jMock makes it relatively easy to define expectations like "invoke x()
> at least once".
>
> As for a /fake/ HTTP request interface, I find myself building that
> thing over and over again. I should ship something, shouldn't I?
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
>
